questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic finding in the fundus examination of a patient with Stargardt disease?

choices.text: Cotton wool spots and Hard exudates

questions.solution:
Answer: (A) Beaten bronze appearance

Explanation:

The following are the characteristic fundus findings seen in Stargardt Disease

  • Beaten bronze appearance on fundus examination

 

 

 

  • Snail line appearance

  • On FFA (Fundus fluorescein angiography) : Dark choroid/ silent choroid sign.




Fig: of Stargardt Disease

 

Stargardt Disease

  • Most common juvenile macular dystrophy.
  • Autosomal recessive
  • It is a dystrophy of the RPE.
  • It is a variant of Fundus flavi-maculatus.
  • It is the most common macular dystrophy.
  • The gene involved is STD most common, ABCA.

 

Clinical features

Symptoms:

  • It manifests in the initial decades.
  • There will be gradual diminishing of central vision. The vision drops to less than 6/60.
  • There will be decreased color vision or impaired dark adaptation.

 

Signs:

  • Beaten bronze appearance
  • Dark choroid/ silent choroid sign
  • Normal FFA: background fluorescence d/t dye in choroidal vessels

 

(Option B) Cotton wool spots and Hard exudates are seen in fundus examination of diabetic retinopathy patients

 

(Option C) Dark choroid/ silent choroid sign is seen on Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA)


 

(Option D) Honey-comb appearance is the characteristic finding in cystoid macular edema

questions.text: A 14-month-old child is diagnosed with retinoblastoma in the right eye. The tumor is confined to the retina, located posterior to equator, measures 2.5 mm in greatest dimension, and is located 3.5 mm from the fovea. There is no vitreous or subretinal seeding. According to the International Classification of Retinoblastoma (ICRB), how would this tumor be classified, and what will be the appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Group A; Systemic chemotherapy with focal consolidation

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Group A; Laser photocoagulation
 

Explanation:

  • The tumor in this case fits Group A criteria of the International Classification of Retinoblastoma:
     
    • Tumor confined to the retina
       
    • Located posterior to the equator
       
    • <3 mm in size
       
    • >3 mm from the fovea and >1.5 mm from the optic disc
       
    • No subretinal or vitreous seeding
       
  • Laser photocoagulation is an appropriate focal treatment for small tumors like this in Group A.
     

International Classification of Retinoblastoma (ICRB)

 

Group

Description

Treatment

Group A

Small intraretinal tumors (<3 mm), away from foveola/optic disc, no seeding

Focal therapy (laser photocoagulation, cryotherapy)

Group B

All remaining discrete tumors confined to retina, any size or location; no seeding

Systemic chemotherapy ± focal therapy

Group C

Local subretinal/vitreous seeding, discrete

Chemotherapy ± focal

Group D

Diffuse seeding

Chemoreduction ± external beam radiation

Group E

Extensive tumor, neovascular glaucoma, opaque media, invasion

Enucleation

 

Group A; Systemic chemotherapy with focal consolidation (Option A):
Incorrect. Group A tumors are treated with focal therapy only, not systemic chemotherapy.
 

Group B; Plaque radiotherapy (Option B):
Incorrect. This tumor does not qualify as Group B. Also, plaque radiotherapy is reserved for select recurrences or larger tumors not suitable for laser.
 

Group B; Enucleation (Option C):
Incorrect. Enucleation is not indicated in Group A or B unless there is treatment failure or vision is unsalvageable.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic with a white pupillary reflex in the right eye, noticed by the parents in flash photography. On examination, the child has strabismus. Which of the following is NOT a condition to be considered in the differential diagnosis of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Optic nerve glioma
 

Explanation:
The case presented describes a classic presentation of retinoblastoma, for which optic nerve glioma is not a differential diagnosis.

Optic nerve gliomas usually present with proptosis, visual loss, and optic nerve swelling, but not typically with leukocoria or an intraocular mass with calcification. Various conditions other than retinoblastoma, which present as leukocoria are collectively called pseudoglioma.

Differential diagnosis of Retinoblastoma

Leukocoria
  • Congenital cataract
  • Inflammatory deposits in vitreous following a plastic cyclitis or choroiditis,
  • Coloboma of the choroid,
  • Retinopathy of prematurity (Option C)
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (Option B)
  • Toxocara endophthalmitis
  • Exudative retinopathy of Coats (Option A)

Endophytic retinoblastoma
  • Tuberous sclerosis
  • Neurofibromatosis
  • Astrocytoma

Exophytic Retinoblastoma
  • Exudative retinopathy of Coats

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with leukocoria in the right eye. Fundus examination reveals a white, elevated mass in the retina. Histopathological examination of the tumor shows rosettes with central lumen. Which of the following is the most specific histological feature for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes

Explanation:

  • The question describes a classic presentation of retinoblastoma, which is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.
  • The key features pointing to this diagnosis are: 
  1. Age of presentation: Retinoblastoma typically occurs in young children, usually before 5 years of age.
  2. Leukocoria: This is the most common presenting sign of retinoblastoma, often described as a white pupillary reflex.
  3. Fundus examination: A white, elevated mass in the retina is characteristic of retinoblastoma.
  • Most specific histopathological feature of retinoblastoma is Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, which are rosettes with a central lumen as shown in the diagram below.

 

 

 

Diagnostic modalities for Retinoblastoma:

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific)- These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes - These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

 

Homer-Wright rosettes (Option A), Pseudorosettes (Option C), Undifferentiated tumor cells (Option D) are histological features seen in retinoblastoma, but are not highly specific.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with the following findings as shown in the image. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the RB1 gene. Which of the following statements best describes the genetic findings associated with this condition?

choices.text: Retinoblastoma can be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, with affected individuals having a 100% chance of passing on the mutation.
Retinoblastoma typically arises from a germline mutation in the RB1 gene, followed by a second somatic mutation.
Affected children with retinoblastoma often have mutations in both the RB1 and TP53 genes.
A single mutation in the RB1 gene is usually sufficient for the development of retinoblastoma in both familial and sporadic cases.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Retinoblastoma typically arises from a germline mutation in the RB1 gene, followed by a second somatic mutation.

 

Explanation:

Retinoblastoma is typically caused by a germline mutation in the RB1 gene (inherited or de novo) followed by a second somatic mutation or "second hit" in the retina, leading to the development of the tumor.

 

Retinoblastoma is caused by inactivation of both alleles of the RB1 tumor suppressor gene. There are two forms:

Heritable (germline):

  • Seen in about 40% of cases, this form often results in bilateral retinoblastoma.
  • It involves a germline mutation of the RB1 gene in all cells, followed by a somatic mutation in the retinal cells.
  • They are prone to develop non-ocular tumors like osteosarcoma.

Non-heritable (sporadic):

  • This form usually involves a unilateral tumor and arises from two somatic mutations that occur in the retinal cells after embryo formation, without a germline mutation.
  • Cannot be passed to offspring and is not prone for developing non-ocular tumors.

 

Knudson’s Two-Hit Hypothesis:

This hypothesis explains the development of retinoblastoma. According to this model:

  • In heritable retinoblastoma, the child inherits a germline mutation in one allele of the RB1 gene (the first hit). A subsequent somatic mutation in the other allele in the retinal cells (the second hit) leads to tumor formation.
  • In sporadic cases, both alleles of the RB1 gene are inactivated by somatic mutations (both hits occurring postnatally).

 

Retinoblastoma can be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, with affected individuals having a 100% chance of passing on the mutation (Option A): While retinoblastoma is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, this option does not explain the second-hit mechanism.

Affected children with retinoblastoma often have mutations in both the RB1 and TP53 genes (Option C): TP53 mutations are seen in Li-Fraumeni syndrome, not in retinoblastoma, which is primarily associated with RB1 mutations.

A single mutation in the RB1 gene is usually sufficient for the development of retinoblastoma in both familial and sporadic cases (Option D): A single mutation in the RB1 gene is insufficient to cause retinoblastoma; a second somatic mutation is required.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of proliferative diabetic retinopathy presents with sudden vision changes in her right eye. She reports seeing floaters and flashes of light. On fundoscopy, there is evidence of fibrous tissue contraction and retinal elevation, but no retinal breaks are seen. What is the most appropriate treatment approach for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pars plana vitrectomy

Explanation:

The patient’s symptoms and fundoscopy findings, including fibrous tissue contraction and retinal elevation without retinal breaks, are consistent with tractional retinal detachment. In this condition, the primary treatment approach is pars plana vitrectomy, which removes the vitreous and addresses the traction caused by the fibrous tissue, thereby relieving the retinal detachment.

 

Clinical features:

  • Presence of vitreoretinal bands associated with the underlying disease.
  • Absence of retinal breaks.
  • A concave, localized detachment that usually does not extend to the ora serrata.
  • Maximum retinal elevation at sites of vitreoretinal traction.
  • Severely reduced retinal mobility with no shifting fluid.
  • Focal traction from cellular membranes can occasionally cause retinal tears, leading to a combined tractional-rhegmatogenous detachment.


 

Treatment for tractional retinal detachment:

  • Pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) is the standard approach for tractional retinal detachment.
  • It involves removing cutting the vitreoretinal tractional bands and internal tamponade with either a long-acting gas or silicon oil.

Treatment for exudative retinal detachment:

  • Treatment focuses on managing the primary disease responsible for the exudative retinal detachment.
  • Since exudative retinal detachment can be caused by transudate, exudate, or hemorrhage, fluid absorption results in the detachment resolving on its own.
  • If the detachment is due to intraocular tumors, enucleation may be necessary.

 

Laser photocoagulation (Option A) is used in proliferative retinopathies to prevent further neovascularization but does not address existing tractional detachment.

 

Cryotherapy with scleral buckling (Option B) is effective in rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, not for tractional detachment.

 

Pneumatic retinopexy (Option D) is not suitable for tractional or exudative detachments, as it primarily addresses rhegmatogenous detachment with retinal breaks.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of flashes of light and a shadow resembling a curtain in the peripheral vision of his right eye. He denies any recent trauma. On examination, fundus evaluation reveals a retinal detachment with a retinal break in the upper temporal quadrant. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Pars plana vitrectomy with silicone oil tamponade
Drainage of subretinal fluid with diathermy to seal the break

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Pneumatic retinopexy with gas injection

Explanation:

This patient has a fresh retinal detachment with a small break in the upper quadrant. Pneumatic retinopexy is an appropriate choice for treating retinal detachments with small breaks in the superior retina.

 

Treatment of Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment:

The primary goals of treating rhegmatogenous retinal detachment are sealing retinal breaks, reducing vitreous traction, and flattening the retina by draining subretinal fluid (SRF) and providing external or internal tamponade.

  1. Sealing Retinal Breaks:
    • All retinal breaks must be identified and sealed by inducing aseptic chorioretinitis.
    • Techniques include cryocoagulation (for scleral buckling and pneumoretinopexy) or endo-laser photocoagulation (during vitrectomy).
  2. Drainage of Subretinal Fluid (SRF):
    • SRF is carefully drained by inserting a fine needle through the sclera and choroid to allow fluid to escape, promoting retinal reattachment.
    • In some cases, SRF drainage may not be necessary.
  3. Maintaining Chorioretinal Apposition:
    • Scleral buckling:
      1. A surgical technique where material sutured onto the sclera (explant) creates an inward indentation (buckle).
      2. It is commonly used in simple cases by inserting a silicone band or sponge.
      3. Scleral buckling is an external retinal detachment surgery, which involves suturing an explant (material) onto the sclera to create an inward indentation (buckle).

  1. The buckle serves to close retinal breaks by pressing the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) against the sensory retina and reduces vitreoretinal traction.
  2. Urgent surgery is necessary for acute retinal detachment if the macula is not involved.
  3. Ideal for retinal detachment secondary to post-traumatic dialysis.

 

  • Pneumatic retinopexy: (Option B)
    1. A minimally invasive quick and OP based procedure to reattach the retina.
    2. Uses an intravitreal gas bubble with cryotherapy or laser to seal retinal breaks.
    3. No scleral buckling is needed.
    4. Common gases: Sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) and perfluoropropane (C3F8).
    5. Used for uncomplicated retinal detachments.
    6. Ideal for small breaks or multiple breaks covering less than two clock hours in the upper peripheral retina.

  1. Vitrectomy and Internal Tamponade:
    • Pars plana vitrectomy is performed for complicated or recurrent cases of RD and tractional detachments.
      1. This involves removing the vitreous, draining SRF, and flattening the retina using silicone oil or perfluorocarbon liquids.
      2. Endolaser photocoagulation is applied around breaks and retinotomy sites to create chorioretinal adhesions, followed by internal tamponade with gas (SF6 or C3F8) or silicone oil.

Intravitreal anti-VEGF injection (Option A): Primarily used for neovascular diseases, such as wet AMD, but not for retinal detachment.

 

Pars plana vitrectomy with silicone oil tamponade (Option C): usually reserved for complicated cases like extensive vitreoretinal traction or multiple breaks. In this case, the detachment is relatively simple, and pneumatic retinopexy is more suitable.

 

Drainage of subretinal fluid with diathermy to seal the break (Option D): While it can be part of the management for retinal detachment, it is not the primary treatment for simple rhegmatogenous detachments with small breaks.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man reports the sudden appearance of flashes of light, followed by a dark cloud or veil in the peripheral vision of his left eye. Examination reveals a greyish reflex in the affected quadrant of the retina. What type of retinal detachment is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment

Explanation:

Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.

 

Etiology:

  • Age: most common in 40-60 years.
  • Sex. More common in males (M:F - 3:2).
  • Myopia. About 40% cases of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment are myopic.
  • Aphakia and pseudophakia.
  • Trauma. It may also act as a predisposing factor.
  • Senile posterior vitreous detachment (PVD): It is associated with retinal detachment in many cases.
  • Retinal degenerations predisposed to retinal detachment: Lattice degeneration, Snail track degeneration, Acquired or degenerative retinoschisis, and Focal pigment clumps.

 

 

Retinal detachment can be classified into three types:

  1. Rhegmatogenous or primary retinal detachment
  2. Tractional retinal detachment
  3. Exudative retinal detachment

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment: This is the most common type and occurs due to a retinal tear or break, allowing subretinal fluid to enter and separate the sensory retina from the pigmentary epithelium.

Tractional Retinal Detachment: Results from the pulling of the retina by fibrous or vascular tissue, commonly seen in fibrovascular proliferative conditions like diabetic retinopathy, without a retinal break.

Exudative Retinal Detachment: Caused due to choroidal pathologies or by tumors pushing the retina or fluid accumulation under the retina due to inflammation or vascular abnormalities, without any associated retinal tear or traction.

Type of Retinal Detachment

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment
  1. Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.
  2. Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.
  3. Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.
  4. Dark veil/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.

  1. Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.
  2. Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.

  1. Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.
  2. Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment
  1. Gradual, progressive visual loss
  2. Typically painless
  3. No associated flashes or floaters
  4. Vitreoretinal bands present
  5. No retinal breaks
  6. Detached area - concave and localized
  7. No shifting fluid

Exudative Retinal Detachment
  1. Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss
  2. No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations.
  3. Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances
  4. Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.
  5. Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature.

 

Tractional Retinal Detachment (Option B): Often seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy or trauma, presenting with gradual vision loss, not acute symptoms.

 

Exudative Retinal Detachment (Option C): Associated with systemic or ocular inflammatory diseases and presents without the classic flashes or floaters.

 

Macular Hole (Option D): Causes central vision loss but does not present with peripheral shadows or flashes.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a mild reduction in vision in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals a "sunny-side up egg" appearance in the macular region with yellowish subretinal material. The child’s father has a similar history of visual impairment since childhood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Best Vitelliform Macular Dystrophy

Explanation:

Best Vitelliform Macular Dystrophy (BVMD), also known as juvenile-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy, is the second most common macular dystrophy after Stargardt disease.

  • Caused by mutations in the BEST1 gene located on chromosome 11q13.
  • Bestrophin, the protein produced by this gene, functions as a transmembrane ion channel in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).
  • Inherited in an autosomal dominant (AD) pattern.
  • Usually begins in childhood

 

Clinical Features:

  • Stages of the disease include:
    • Pre-vitelliform: abnormal EOG, normal fundus in asymptomatic patients.
    • Vitelliform: a characteristic "egg yolk or sunny-side up" macular lesion. The lesions can vary in size and developmental stage between the two eyes.

  • Pseudohypopyon: partially regressed lesion.
  • Vitelliruptive: Lesion fragments, visual acuity declines - “scrambled egg appearance”.

  • Atrophic: Pigment disappears, leading to RPE atrophy.
  • Visual acuity - stable early on but declines in adulthood due to complications like choroidal neovascularization (CNV), scarring, or geographic atrophy.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Fundus Autofluorescence (FAF): hyper autofluorescence yellowish material.
  • Fluorescein Angiography (FA): hypofluorescence due to lesion masking.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): hyperreflective material beneath and within the RPE.
  • Electro-oculography (EOG): Severely subnormal across all stages (Arden index <1.5).
  • Hallmark- normal electroretinogram (ERG) but abnormal electrooculogram (EOG).

 

Stargardt Disease (Option A): Causes central vision loss with a characteristic "beaten-bronze" appearance and yellow flecks but is not associated with the vitelliform lesion.

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa (Option C): Characterized by night blindness and peripheral vision loss, not macular lesions.

 

Leber Congenital Amaurosis (Option D): A severe form of retinal dystrophy with early-onset blindness but lacks the specific macular changes seen in BVMD.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with progressive vision loss. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes a central scotoma and yellowish-white flecks in the macular region of the retina. A diagnosis of Stargardt disease is made. All of the following are true statements about Stargardt disease, except:

choices.text: It is also known as juvenile macular dystrophy
Vitamin A supplementation should be avoided

questions.solution:
Answer: (B) Fundus examination showing flame-shaped hemorrhages

 

Explanation:

Fundus examination showing flame-shaped hemorrhages is seen in hypertensive retinopathy.

All other options are true regarding Stargardt disease.

 

Stargardt disease, also known as juvenile macular dystrophy, is the most common macular dystrophy. (Option A)

 

Investigations:

  • FFA: A dye is injected, and there is a dark background choroid fluorescence due to dense deposition of lipofuscin on retinal pigment epithelium.
  • Since there's no choroidal background fluorescence seen, it is called "dark choroid syndrome" or "silent choroid syndrome".
  • Fundus autofluorescence: No dye is seen, and all lipofuscin deposits are shining. (Option D)
  • EOG abnormality.
  • ERG: Late stages may affect the ERG, mainly photopic ERG abnormality.

 

Treatment

  • Avoid bright sunlight. Use sunglasses
  • Avoid vitamin A, as it promotes lipofuscinosis. (Option C)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with sudden distrubunce of vision in his right eye for two weeks. He reports distortion of images. He has been intermittently using corticosteroids for allergies. His Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/18. FFA and OCT findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Central serous chorioretinopathy

Explanation:

This patient’s sudden onset of painless vision loss, stress, corticosteroid use, and characteristic FFA "smoke-stack (mushroom-shaped)" pattern with subretinal fluid seen on OCT strongly suggest central serous chorioretinopathy.

 

Central Serous Chorioretinopathy (CSCR)

CSCR is characterized by the spontaneous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region, with or without retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) detachment.

 

Pathogenesis: Increased sympathetic drive and corticosteroids affect choroidal vascular permeability, raising hydrostatic pressure, and leading to RPE defects and serous detachment of the neurosensory retina.

 

Risk Factors:

  • Males aged 20-50
  • Type A personality
  • Emotional stress
  • Steroid use
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus, Cushing's disease
  • Pregnancy (3rd trimester)

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Sudden painless vision loss (6/9 - 6/24)
  • Relative positive scotoma, micropsia, and metamorphopsia
  • Recurrence in 30-50% of cases

 

Examination Findings:

  • Mild macular elevation with circular ring reflex
  • RPE detachment (yellow-grey elevations)
  • Absence or distortion of the foveal reflex
  • Subretinal deposits

 

Investigations:

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA): Shows "ink-blot" or "smoke-stack" leakage patterns.

serous retinopathy" data-author="" data-hash="12381" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/60Kyy7eEGrAeACMgIVAU1746690458.png" />

 

  • Indocyanine green (ICG): Shows hyperfluorescence due to choroidal hyperpermeability.
  • OCT: Shows neurosensory retinal and RPE detachment.

 

 

Treatment:

 

 

  1. Conservative: Reassurance; spontaneous resolution in 80-90% of cases within 1-6 months.
  2. Laser Photocoagulation: For cases lasting more than 3 months, recurrent cases, and those with permanent vision loss in the other eye due to CSCR.
  3. Photodynamic Therapy (PDT): For severe, sub-foveal leaks, or chronic cases.
  4. Anti-VEGF: Considered if choroidal neovascularization (CNV) develops.

 

Age-related macular degeneration (Option B): ARMD typically occurs in older patients (>50) and is associated with drusen and neovascularization, which are absent here.

 

Cystoid macular edema (Option C): CME usually follows ocular surgeries or inflammation and presents with cystic spaces on OCT, not the subretinal detachment seen here.

 

Retinal vein occlusion (Option D): RVO presents with retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots on examination, not the isolated macular elevation and leakage seen in CSCR.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Answer: (D) Conductive deafness

Explanation:

Retinitis pigmentosa associated with sensory neural deafness- Usher syndrome

 

Systemic associations in Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Refsum's disease: It is a defect in the phytanic acid metabolism. RP+ Cerebellar ataxia+ Polyneuropathy. It is managed with a low phytanic acid diet. (Option A)
  • Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl syndrome (m/c): involves RP, mental retardation, obesity, polydactyly, and paraplegia. (Option B)
  • Usher's syndrome: It is retinitis pigmentosa (RP) with Sensory neural deafness.
  • Kearns-Sayer syndrome: involves RP, heart block, and chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO). (Option C)
  • Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome involves RP, acanthocytosis, abetalipoproteinemia, and ataxia. It is managed with a low-fat diet and vitamin supplements.

 

Ocular associations in Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Keratoconus
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC)
  • Open-angle glaucoma (OAG)
  • Cystoid macular edema (CME)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with progressive night blindness and gradual loss of peripheral vision over the past few years. Her family history reveals that her father had similar symptoms. On examination, you observe characteristic retinal changes, including bone spicule pigmentation. To evaluate the functional status of her retina more accurately, which diagnostic test would you choose to confirm the suspicion of retinitis pigmentosa (RP)?
questions.solution:
Answer: (A) Electroretinography (ERG)

Explanation:

ERG is a sensitive diagnostic test in retinitis pigmentosa that shows reduced scotopic, subnormal responses in early disease and becomes completely extinguished in advanced disease.

 

Investigation of Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Electroretinography (ERG) is the investigation of choice - reduced scotopic rod in early disease and reduced photopic with progression. (Option A)
  • EOG - subnormal - absence of light rise. (Option D)
  • Perimetry: initially small mid-peripheral scotomas which gradually merge and may progress, leaving only a small island of residual central vision.
  • Electroretinography (ERG): There's a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.
  • OCT - to identify cystoid macular edema (CME).(Option B)
  • Dark adaptometry: Dark adaptation time is prolonged.
  • Decreased Arden ratio may be present.

Treatment of Retinitis Pigmentosa:

  • The treatable RP includes Refsum's disease and Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome.

The treatment includes-

  • Regular follow-ups: Annual check-ups help detect complications, provide support, and track new treatment options.
  • Low-vision aids: Includes devices, rehabilitation, and access to social services. Avoid smoking.
  • Light protection:
    • Outdoor sunglasses blocking wavelengths up to 550 nm with side protection.
    • Indoors, amber lenses blocking 511–527 nm may enhance contrast sensitivity.
  • Treatment for CMO: Oral acetazolamide or topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors may reduce cystoid macular edema.
  • Vitamin A: High-dose vitamin A (15,000 units/day) provides marginal benefits but should be used with caution due to risks like liver toxicity and increased lung cancer risk in smokers. Avoid during pregnancy. Lutein, possibly with zeaxanthin, is a safer alternative.
  • A retinal implant (ARGUS-II) can also be performed.
  • Low-vision aids (LVA) can also be used.
  • It can also lead to cone dystrophy.


 

Visual field testing (Option C) is important for evaluating the extent of vision loss, especially in RP where peripheral vision is often affected. However, it does not directly assess the functional status of the retinal photoreceptors.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old female presents with difficulty seeing in low light and peripheral vision loss that has gradually worsened over several years. On fundoscopy, the following findings are noted.



Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retinitis Pigmentosa

Explanation:

The image given above is retinitis pigmentosa fundoscopy findings showing a pale waxy disc, bony spicules, and attenuation of arteries.

The Triad of retinitis pigmentosa includes a pale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a dystrophy of rods and cones, initially, rods are affected.
  • Most common hereditary fundus dystrophy.
  • It can be sporadic (40-50%) or hereditary.
  • If hereditary, autosomal dominant is the most common mode of inheritance followed by autosomal recessive (AR). X-linked recessive inheritance is the least severe form.

 

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Nyctalopia (night blindness)
  • Peripheral visual field loss
  • Mid-peripheral superior scotoma leads to ring/ doughnut scotoma resulting in tubular/ tunnel vision

Signs:

  • Triad of a pale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.
  • Tapetal reflex: shining reflex at macula - seen in female carriers of XLR inheritance.

 

Atypical Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Atypical retinitis pigmentosa includes heterogeneous disorders that share clinical features with typical pigmentary retinal dystrophy.
  • Conditions included are:

RP sine pigmento - absence or paucity of pigment accumulation

 

 

  • Retinitis punctata albescens - scattered whitish-yellow spots with arteriolar attenuation, usually sparing the macula.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with gradual central vision loss in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals concentric rings of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) atrophy and hyperpigmentation centred on the fovea, creating a characteristic appearance. The image showing the appearance is given below:



 

Which of the following is least likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chronic central serous chorioretinopathy

 

Explanation:

  • The image shows the characteristic appearance of Bull's eye maculopathy, a retinal disorder characterised by concentric rings of RPE atrophy and hyperpigmentation centred on the fovea, creating an appearance resembling a bull's eye target.
  • While chronic central serous chorioretinopathy can cause retinal pigment epithelium changes, it typically does not present with the characteristic bull's eye maculopathy appearance.

 

Etiological causes of bull’s eye maculopathy include:

  • Chloroquine maculopathy (Option C)
  • Hydroxychloroquine (Option A)
  • Cone dystrophy (Option B)
  • Battens disease

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with gradual vision loss in her right eye over the past 6 months. Her ophthalmologist suspects age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and orders further tests. What is the most sensitive modality to detect exudative AMD?

choices.text: Slit-lamp biomicroscopy using a +90 or +78 D lens

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT)

Explanation:

OCT is currently considered the most sensitive modality for detecting exudative (wet) AMD.

 

 

Dry AMD

Wet AMD

Diagnostic Methods
  • Slit-lamp biomicroscopy using a +90 or +78 D lens (Clinical diagnosis)
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): outer retinal tubulation is seen in the outer nuclear layer.
  • Fundus autofluorescence
  • Amsler grid test
  • Slit-lamp biomicroscopy using a +90 or +78 D lens
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) (Most sensitive): RPE detachment is seen.
  • Fluorescein angiography
  • Indocyanine green angiography

Treatment Options
  • AREDS supplements (vitamins C, E, zinc, copper, lutein, zeaxanthin)
  • Lifestyle modifications (smoking cessation, healthy diet)
  • Regular monitoring to prevent progression to advanced disease
  • Intravitreal anti-VEGF injections (e.g., bevacizumab, ranibizumab, aflibercept)
  • Photodynamic therapy (in select cases)
  • Rarely, laser photocoagulation (for extrafoveal CNV)

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with gradual vision loss in both eyes over the past year. His ophthalmologist diagnoses him with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Which of the following statements about AMD is correct?

choices.text: AMD is a hereditary degeneration exclusively affecting the macula
Wet AMD accounts for 90% of all AMD cases but only 10% of severe vision loss
Dry AMD is characterised by choroidal neovascularisation
AMD is the most common cause of permanent central visual loss after 6th decade

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) AMD is the most common cause of permanent central visual loss after 6th decade

 

Explanation:

Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD) is a nonhereditary degeneration involving the choriocapillaris, Bruch's membrane, retinal pigment epithelium, and photoreceptors. It is indeed the most common cause of permanent central visual loss after 6th decade.

 

Based on the clinical findings of macular degeneration, It is of 2 types:

 

  • Exudative (wet)
  • Non-exudative (dry)

 

Category

Dry AMD

Wet AMD

Definition

Nonexudative macular degeneration

Exudative macular degeneration

Prevalence

90% of all AMD cases

10% of all AMD cases

Vision Loss

Accounts for about 10% of legal blindness in AMD

Major blinding form, accounts for 90% of severe vision loss in AMD

Key Features

Drusen, RPE abnormalities, geographic atrophy

Choroidal neovascularization (CNV), subretinal fluid

Pathophysiology

Accumulation of drusen, dysfunction of RPE

Growth of new blood vessels from choroid, leakage of fluid

Progression

Generally slow

Can be rapid

 

DRY AMD:

 

(Option A) AMD is a nonhereditary degeneration primarily affecting the macula involving the choriocapillaris, Bruch's membrane, retinal pigment epithelium, and photoreceptors.

 

(Option B) Wet AMD accounts for only 10% of all AMD cases but is responsible for 90% of severe vision loss in AMD patients.

 

(Option C) Choroidal neovascularization is a characteristic of wet AMD, not dry AMD. Dry AMD is characterized by drusen, RPE abnormalities, and geographic atrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about angioid streaks is incorrect?

choices.text: They represent breaks in Bruch's membrane
They are commonly associated with sickle cell anemia
Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) frequently develops in these patients
Steroids are primarily used for the prevention of CNV

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Steroids are primarily used for the prevention of CNV

Explanation:

Angioid streaks are crack-like dehiscences in Bruch's membrane, appearing as irregular reddish-brown or gray lines radiating from the optic disc.

Bruch's membrane: The innermost layer of the choroid is the Bruch's membrane. It is a membrane between the choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium.

It lines the layer of choriocapillaris.

 

  • Asymptomatic angioid streaks do not require treatment.
  • However, anti-VEGF therapy can be used to prevent choroidal neovascularization.


Angioid Streaks:

Definition

Crack-like dehiscences in Bruch's membrane, appearing as reddish-brown or gray lines radiating from the optic disc (Option A)

Association with conditions
  • Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE) - Most common
  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
  • Paget's disease
  • Sickle cell disease (Option B)

Complication

Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) frequently develops in affected patients (Option C)

Treatment

Anti-VEGF therapy for choroidal neovascularization

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of high myopia since childhood presents for a routine eye examination. She reports occasional floaters and difficulty seeing at night. On fundus examination, the ophthalmologist notes a tilted optic disc, peripapillary atrophy, and a myopic crescent. Which of the following is NOT typically associated with the condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Optic disc edema

Explanation:

The patient's history and fundus findings are consistent with pathological myopia.

  • Pathological myopia is a progressive form of myopia characterized by excessive axial elongation of the eyeball and degenerative changes in the retina and choroid.
  • The optic disc in pathological myopia often appears large and pale due to the stretching of the eye, but it is not edematous.

 

Pathological Myopia

Definition

Pathological/degenerative/progressive myopia is a rapidly progressive error that starts in childhood at 5-10 years of age and results in high myopia (>-6D) during early adult life.

Etiology
  • Rapid axial growth of the eyeball outside normal biological variations
  • Genetic factors (major role)
    • More common in women than men
    • Autosomal dominant pathological myopia
    • Heredity-
      • Familial, more common in women and in certain races
      • Autosomal Dominant - linked to genes 18p11.31 and 12q21-23
      • Sex-linked recessive - high myopia (>6D)
  • General growth process (minor role)
    • nutritional deficiency
    • endocrine disturbances

Symptoms
  • Defective vision with considerable failure in visual function
  • Muscae volitantes (floaters)
  • Difficulty in night vision in very high myopes with degenerative changes

Signs
  • Prominent eyeballs, often appear elongated
  • Exophthalmos, especially in unilateral cases
  • Cornea is large
  • The anterior chamber is deep
  • Pupils are slightly large and react sluggishly to light
  • Fundus examination reveals:
    • The optic disc appears large and pale
    • Characteristic myopic crescent
    • Tigroid fundus
    • Myopic crescent (temporal to disc margin)

Complications
  • Retinal detachment
  • Complicated cataract
  • Choroidal hemorrhage and neovascularization
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma (associated condition)
  • Degenerative changes in the retina and choroid:
    • Chorioretinal atrophy at the macula

  • Foster-Fuchs spots (Option A)

  • Lattice degeneration (Option B)

  • Total retinal atrophy
  • Posterior staphyloma (Option C)

  • Degenerative changes in vitreous:
    • Liquefaction
    • Vitreous opacities
    • Posterior vitreous detachment

questions.text: A 65-year-old presents with visual blurring in the left eye, 20/40 vision, and a history of cataract surgery three months ago. Fundus examination shows retinal thickening and a dull foveal reflex. OCT and FFA findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cystoid Macular Edema

 

Explanation:

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) is associated with fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers of the retina, leading to cystoid spaces.

  • The OCT findings of multiple cystic spaces centered around the foveola.
  • Fundus Fluorescein Angiography shows leakage and dye accumulation in the macular region, with a "flower petal appearance" in late frames.
  • The history of recent cataract surgery further supports this diagnosis, as CME is a known postoperative complication. (also known as Irvine gass syndrome)

 

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME)

Etiology:

  • Ocular Treatment Complications: Post-surgery (e.g., cataract extraction, retinal detachment surgery), ocular laser therapy, and topical ocular medications.
  • Retinal Vascular Disorders: Diabetic retinopathy, central and branch retinal vein occlusion, retinal telangiectasia, and hypertensive retinopathy.
  • Intraocular Inflammations: Pars planitis, uveitis.
  • Retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Vitreomacular Traction: Associated with macular epiretinal membrane (ERM) and vitreomacular traction (VMT) syndrome.
  • Systemic Diseases: Includes leukemia, chronic renal failure, and multiple myeloma.
  • Miscellaneous Causes:niacin toxicity , PG analogues (risk factor for development of CME)

Clinical Features:

  • Visual Loss: Initial minimal to moderate vision loss, potentially leading to permanent vision decrease if persistent.
  • Ophthalmoscopy: Reveals loss of foveal contour, retinal thickening, and a "honeycomb appearance" of the macula.
  • Fluorescein Angiography: Shows leakage and dye accumulation in the macular region, with a "flower petal appearance" in late frames.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Demonstrates loss of foveal depression, cystoid spaces, and overall retinal thickening.

 

Complications:

  • Long-standing CME may result in a lamellar macular hole.

 

Treatment:

  • Addressing the Cause: Intravitreal anti-VEGF or photocoagulation for diabetic CME; discontinuing causative topical medications.
  • Topical NSAIDs: Such as ketorolac, diclofenac, or profenac, are effective in preventing and treating CME.
  • Topical/Systemic Steroids: Useful in established cases.
  • Systemic Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors (CAIs): Oral acetazolamide may be beneficial, particularly in cases associated with retinitis pigmentosa.

 

Diabetic Retinopathy (Option A):

  • Typically shows diffuse retinal thickening and other diabetic changes, not the cystoid spaces seen in CME.

 

Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (Option B):

  • Often associated with retinal hemorrhages and diffuse edema, but CME's cystoid spaces are more specific.

 

Central Serous Retinopathy (Option D) is characterized by "ink-blot" or "smoke-stack" leakage patterns on FFA, and neurosensory retinal and RPE detachment on OCT.

  • CSR typically does not present with the cystoid pattern seen in CME.
